titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Robert A. Caro Archive
[DATE]–2021
MS 3203
titlestmt.author: Joseph Ditta (2022-2023)

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-02-28 14:18:39 -0500.

physdesc.extent: in # record cartons, # flat boxes, # scrapbooks, . . .

did.abstract: Papers of Pulitzer Prize and National Book Award winner Robert A. Caro, author of The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York (1974), the seminal study on the uses and abuses of political power, and of The Years of Lyndon Johnson (1982–ongoing), his massively-detailed biography of the 36th President of the United States. In addition to the copious research and interview notes, manuscript and typed drafts, and galley proofs documenting the creation of these works, the collection includes material from Caro's earliest efforts, when he edited and contributed to his high school and college newspapers (Horace Mann, class of 1953; Princeton, class of 1957). Also present are files from Caro's years as a newspaper reporter for Newsday, where his investigations exposed, among other scandals, the fraudulent dealings of real estate brokers who duped retirees into buying worthless land by mail. A series of scrapbooks details Caro's working life through book reviews, profiles, interviews, photographs, awards, and ephemera.
did.langmaterial: The documents in the collection are in English.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchase, Robert A. Caro, Inc., 2020 [USING ANY PARTICULAR FUNDS THAT MUST BE MENTIONED?]

defitem.label: [Series VIII.]

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I contains pieces written by Caro during his high school and college years. A scrapbook holds scattered issues of the "Horace Mann Record" his Bronx high school newspaper, which he edited, for 1952-1953. The issue of May 12, 1952 announces his appointment as editor. Note also the issue of December 8, 1952 (vol. XLVI, no. 11), which exists in English and Russian-language editions; Caro produced the latter and sent 10,000 copies to students in the USSR. At Princeton, Caro contributed to the "Daily Princetonian," of which he was also managing editor. Series I includes a number of his "Ivy Inklings" columns, which covered matches of Princeton's athletic teams, as well as profiles of faculty (see the series "Princeton's Great Lecturers" March 24-31, 1955) and fellow students ("Senior Weds, Ending Car and Cooking Worries," September 28, 1954).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material in Series I is in chronological order, with minor deviations.

did.unittitle: "Robert A. Caro. The Horace Mann record. Horace Mann School, 1952" (Scrapbook [A])

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Loose clippings, mostly of Caro's "Ivy Inklings" sports column; originally housed in an envelope marked "Daily Princetonian Stories, 1954–1955" and placed inside the front cover of the scrapbook embossed "Robert A. Caro. The Horace Mann record. Horace Mann School, 1952." An earlier clipping, dated November 18, 1953, announcing Caro's appointment as assistant editor, appears near the end of the Horace Mann scrapbook. And a photocopy of a later piece, "Morris Bucks for Winning Touchdown As Penn Goal-Line Stands Slow Tigers," from the issue of October 10, 1955, appears in Scrapbook [24] (see Series XI).
Complete, digitized issues of The Daily Princetonian, 1876–2015, are available online at theprince.princeton.edu.

did.unittitle: Subseries II.A. Newsday research files [cabinet 2 / drawer 2]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drawer labeled "Novel: Rough draft; Home News: Dollar dilemma; Newsday: Files for 'Misery Acres'." (original drawer label from file cabinet 2 is in Box P51)
Larry's survey notes . . .

Cabinet 2, drawer 2, box P53: Typescript draft(s?) of a novel "News Man." 24 folders from Newsday era: Most labeled as "Land Scandals" and others likely related ("Misery Acres," "Auerbach Inc.", "Crooks," etc.). Original documents compiled by Caro during his research, letters to him related to the scandals, Caro's notes, including at least one off the record interview (with Claude Pepper of Florida). Transcript of taped interview between Caro and Dory Auerbach.
Cabinet 2, drawer 2, box P54: 14 folders continued from above re: land scandals, including Florida and Arizona/Southwest

did.unittitle: Subseries II.B. Newsday research files [cabinet 2 / drawer 3]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drawer labeled "Newsday: Files for Suffolk: Sick Giant; Waldemar, Keating & World's Fair '64." On back of label: "Novel-Rough." (original drawer label from file cabinet 2 is in Box P51)
WALDEMAR = Waldemar Medical Research Foundation, Inc. / Waldemar Cancer Research and Prevention Center, Woodbury, Long Island
Larry's survey notes . . .

Cabinet 2, drawer 3, box P55: 23 folders all with main heading of "Suffolk." Probably for different articles. Material here on taxes, LILCO, a bridge, unemployment, transportation, etc. Caro's notes from sources (some gathered in "typed notes" folder). Clippings with the articles he wrote. Many original documents.

Cabinet 2, drawer 3, box P56: 26 folders. Most are on topic of "Waldemar," a medical research foundation: Clips of Caro's stories, background documents, etc. Folder on "Suit" includes a thick memo from Caro to Andy Hughes (attorney?) detailing his work on the topic. 3 more Suffolk folders (continuing from above), 3 folders on the 1964 World's Fair (appears to have something to do with finances and executive expenses). 2 folders on Ken Keating 1964 campaign for senator and Caro's articles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [Trunk 3] Power Broker [crossed out] Newsday (MSS material) (4 of 5 boxes)

These contents all appear to relate to Caro's Newsday years. Many folders on topics: insecticides, franchises, Cahn-Nickerson jukebox riot, Speno land case, anatomy of a burglary. Pile of loose documents: Clippings, photostats/Thermofax of police reports, etc., typed notes. Useful for exhibition perhaps: many reprints of Caro's Misery Acres articles in Newsday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Research and notes for Caro's Newsday piece, "The Legal Mogul, Or, How a Struggling Young Law Student Became Sidney R. Siben, Esq." Includes four copies of the published article, which ran on April 24, 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes various governmental pamphlets and publications, such as a comic book issued by the Food and Drug Administration, "Dennis the Menace Takes a Poke at Poison" (1961).

A volume of Robert Caro's "Misery Acres" series for Newsday, compiled for submission to the 1964 National Headliners Awards committee.

[52a] "The Newsday articles were widely reprinted . . ."
[52b–54] [Examples of Misery Acres reprints from nationwide newspapers.]
[55a] "These letters are typical of the many received . . ."
[55b–65] Letters of appreciation on "Misery Acres" series.

[66] Photo of Caro with brief bio: "Robert A. Caro joined Newsday in 1959 as a reporter and rewrite man. Before joining this newspaper, he worked for two years as a reporter for the New Brunswick Daily Home News and Sunday Times, New Brunswick, N.J. / A native of New York City, Caro was graduated from the Horace Mann School for Boys with the highest honors in 1953. He attended Princeton University, where he was managing editor of The Daily Princetonian. He was graduated magna cum laude in 1957. / Caro is 28, married and the father of one son, Chase Arthur. The Caros live in Oceanside, Long Island, N.Y."
[inside back cover] "Bridge to Rhode Island is Vital to Prosperity," Newsday reprint of articles by Caro and others, October 4–November 1, 1963 [2 copies].
[inside back cover] Folder belonging with Power Broker files: "Macy:—Banking Investigation."

did.unittitle: Nomination submission for Pulitzer Prize in Journalism for Newsday series "Suffolk: The Sick Giant" (Scrapbook [C])

did.unittitle: Series III. The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York (published 1974)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III holds Robert Caro's Power Broker research files (containing interview notes, clippings and summaries from various newspapers and magazines, book passages, and some correspondence), interview notebooks, print matter (upwards of one hundred publications issued by Robert Moses or one of his public authorities over a forty-year period), typed drafts, galley proofs (both the drafts and galleys bear numerous corrections and emendations by Caro and his editors), promotional material, and oversized framed photographs and objects.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is subdivided as follows:

defitem.label: Subseries III.J.
defitem.item: Power Broker oversize material and objects, [DATE-DATE]

odd.head: Abbreviations and acronyms from Caro's file labels and notes to the Power Broker:
odd.p:
ASHPS = American Scenic and Historical Preservation Society
BBT = Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel
BMR = Bureau of Municipal Research
BPR = Bureau of Public Roads
CCC = City Construction Coordinator
CON-CON = (New York State) Constitutional Convention
CPC = City Planning Commission
DN = New York Daily News
DPW = State Department of Public Works
EAGLE = Brooklyn Daily Eagle
FDR = Franklin Delano Roosevelt
FM = Flushing Meadows Corona Park
HT = Herald Tribune
Impy = Vincent R. Impellitteri
J-A = New York Journal-American
LAG = Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia
LI = Long Island
LIE = Long Island Expressway
LIRR = Long Island Rail Road
LISPC = Long Island State Park Commission
M = Robert Moses
MCTA = Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority
MRTC = Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission
NYC = New York City
NYT = New York Times
OHR = Oral History Reminiscence(s)
O'D = William O'Dwyer
PD = Park(s) Department
PEM = Paul Emanuel Moses
POST = New York Post
PWA = Public Works Administration
RM = Robert Moses
TA = New York City Tunnel Authority
TBA = Triborough Bridge Authority
TBTA = Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority
WAG = Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr.
WF = New York World's Fair (1964-1965 : New York, N.Y.)
WPA = Works Progress Administration
WSI = West Side Improvement
WT = New York World-Telegram
WT&S = New York World-Telegram and Sun
Black Papers = questionnaires and reports on displaced tenants on Moses' Title I sites compiled by Elinor Black, chairman, housing committee, Women's City Club
Cook Papers = memos on Title I scandals of the 1950s, written by Gene Gleason and other New York World-Telegram reporters to rewriteman Fred J. Cook
Maurice P. Davidson Papers = Davidson family
Edelstein Papers = documents collected by Lillian Edelstein during fight against Cross-Bronx Expressway (in her possession)
Exton Papers = letters, memos, and informal diaries of reformer William Exton, which detail his battles during the 1930s against the West Side Highway and the remodeling of Washington Square Park; kept at family's home in Millbrook, Dutchess County
Gabel Papers = documents Hortense Gabel gave Caro from her time as Deputy State Housing Rent Administrator
Gaus Papers = internal memoranda and draft reports of the State Reconstruction Commission, preserved by commission staffer John M. Gaus at his home in Utica
Impellitteri Papers = Municipal Archives
Kahn Papers = letters, memos, and secret internal documents relating to Moses' 1964-65 World's Fair obtained by New York Post reporter Joseph Kahn and given to Caro
Kopple Papers = collection of memoranda and files given to Caro by Robert Kopple, "true creator of the 1964-65 World's Fair"
La Guardia Papers = Municipal Archives
Levitt TBTA Audit =
Levitt TBTA LISPC Audit =
Macy Papers = personal files of W. Kingsland Macy, State Republican Chairman (1930-1934), Suffolk County Republican Chairman (1927-1960)
Henry Morgenthau Jr. Diary = Roosevelt Library, New Hyde Park
O'Dwyer Papers = Municipal Archives
Oral History Project = Columbia
Park Department Files = internal memoranda of the New York City Park(s) Department, stored in 79th Street Boat Basin
Joseph M. Price Papers = Butler Library, Columbia
Franklin D. Roosevelt Papers = Roosevelt Library, New Hyde Park
Alfred E. Smith Papers = New York State Library
Henry L. Stimson Papers = Sterling Library, Yale University
Thompson Papers = various other documents relating to Title I given to Caro by Stephen G. Thompson of the New York Herald Tribune
Wagner Papers = Municipal Archives
Zeckendorf Papers = copies of letters and memos relating to creation of U.N. Headquarters given to Caro by William Zeckendorf

did.unittitle: Subseries III.A. Power Broker research files [cabinet drawer 1]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files from drawer 1 of the four-drawer cabinet holding Caro's Power Broker research. The drawer labels read: "Youth (1888–1911)"; "The Young Reformer (1912–1918)"; and "The Rise to Power (1919–1933)." Contains research and interview notes (handwritten and typed), newspaper clippings from the New York Times, Herald Tribune, Brooklyn Eagle and others (some are photocopies or printouts, but a substantial portion are originals, and many have been transcribed/summarized by Caro), magazine articles, book passages, and other print matter, and some correspondence. Of particular note are the oral history reminiscences of associates of New York Governor Al Smith, and the interviews with Paul Moses (brother of Robert) and with Moses himself (which exist here as photocopies).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files are presented in their original order. Caro's letter-size folders—some of which carry notes on their covers or interiors—have been maintained and grouped inside archival, legal-size folders. Caro's folder titles are keyed to these numbered archival folders. Titles have been transcribed as near to how Caro wrote them as possible, following his capitalization and underlining; any clarifications by the archivist, such as expansions of abbreviations or acronyms, follow in square brackets, e.g., "1914—MCPL C.S. COM [Municipal Civil Service Commission]."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Label 1 of 2 (placed in front of one below):
THE POWER BROKER / YOUTH (1888-1911) / THE YOUNG REFORMER (1912-1918)
Label 2 of 2 (placed behind one above):
THE RISE TO POWER (1919-1933)

did.unittitle: Subseries III.B. Power Broker research files [cabinet drawer 2]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files from drawer 2 of the four-drawer cabinet holding Caro's Power Broker research. The drawer label read: "The Growth of Power (1934–1945)." Contains research and interview notes (handwritten and typed), newspaper clippings from the New York Times, Herald Tribune, Brooklyn Eagle and others (some are photocopies or printouts, but a substantial portion are originals, and many have been transcribed/summarized by Caro), magazine articles, book passages, and other print matter, and some correspondence. The files here are largely subject oriented, e.g., "Central Park," "East River Drive," etc. Note the folder "My Trips to Parks," which contains Caro's descriptive notes on visits to the Moses-created Heckscher State Park, Hempstead Lake State Park, Jones Beach, and West Hempstead Lake Park on Long Island.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files are presented in their original order. Caro's letter-size folders—some of which carry notes on their covers or interiors—have been maintained and grouped inside archival, legal-size folders. Caro's folder titles are keyed to these numbered archival folders. Titles have been transcribed as near to how Caro wrote them as possible, following his capitalization and underlining; any clarifications by the archivist, such as expansions of abbreviations or acronyms, follow in square brackets, e.g., "MID-MAN XWY: LAG [Mid-Manhattan Expressway: La Guardia]."

Subseries III.D. Power Broker research files [cabinet drawer 4]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files from drawer 4 of the four-drawer cabinet holding Caro's Power Broker research. The drawer label read: "The Loss of Power (1961–1968)." Contains research and interview notes (handwritten and typed), newspaper clippings from the New York Times, Herald Tribune, Brooklyn Eagle and others (some are photocopies or printouts, but a substantial portion are originals, and many have been transcribed/summarized by Caro), magazine articles, book passages, and other print matter, and some correspondence. Note the folders on various New York City expressways built and aborted: Gowanus, Cross-Bronx, Lower Manhattan (LOMEX). A few relate to Caro's creative decision-making process and are marked "Thoughts" or "Put In." The folder "My Letters" includes one from a New York City Parks Department official granting Caro and key and access to records.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files are presented in their original order. Caro's letter-size folders—some of which carry notes on their covers or interiors—have been maintained and grouped inside archival, legal-size folders. Caro's folder titles are keyed to these numbered archival folders. Titles have been transcribed as near to how Caro wrote them as possible, following his capitalization and underlining; any clarifications by the archivist, such as expansions of abbreviations or acronyms, follow in square brackets, e.g., "OPENING OF FM PARK [Flushing Meadows–Corona Park]."

did.unittitle: Subseries III.F. Power Broker research print matter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: As recorded by Caro in "A Note on Sources" to The Power Broker (p. 1169), the materials in this subseries are likely the "more than one hundred brochures written or edited during a period of more than forty years by Robert Moses and published by one of his public authorities or the Mayor's Slum Clearance Committee or the New York City Park Department [that] were given to the author by Sidney M. Shapiro." Publications include "North Shore of Jamaica Bay" (1949); a feasibility report on a "Proposed Liberty Bridge Over Upper New York Bay" (1958); a press packet for the "Dedication, George Washington Bridge Bus Station and Alexander Hamilton Bridge" (1963); a pamphlet for the dedication of the "Meadowbrook Causeway and Long Beach Loop, Jones Beach State Park" (1934); a program for the cornerstone laying ceremony of Lincoln Square / Lincoln Towers (1961); and an undated narrative by John Rolfe, "A Neighborhood Organizes to Fight City Hall," documenting community efforts to block construction of the Cross-Bronx Expressway. Many items have been underlined and annotated by Caro with research questions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The items here are filed chronologically, with some internal groupings by publishing agency (e.g., New York City Parks Department progress reports for 1940-1964).

did.unittitle: The State Park Plan for New York
[Pauchogue Land Corporation vs. Long Island State Park Commission and Robert Moses]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
• Supreme Court, Suffolk County. Pauchogue Land Corporation, Plaintiff, against Long Island State Park Commission, and Robert Moses . . . defendants. scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Multiple typed, partial drafts of chapters or portions of chapters of the Power Broker, many showing cross-outs and emendations by Caro.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The drafts are presented, roughly, in the order in which they were encountered. Since not every draft bears the title to which it belongs, determining the sequence of pages proves challenging, especially as numbering schemes evolved during the creative process, e.g., single- to quadruple-digit numbers vs. hyphenated numbers in which the first two digits apparently represent the chapter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Galleys or galley proofs—so-called after the tray, or galley, that held printers' type—are preliminary or trial sheets of text, often produced in long, continuous strips, printed for the checking of typographical or other errors. Shared among a work's author, editor, and printer, they bear deletions, additions, and other emendations made to the text before final publication. These galleys of The Power Broker show considerable changes by Caro and others (one set is marked "Gottlieb's," indicating it was the copy of Caro's editor, Robert Gottlieb), often in the form of pencil cross-outs and manuscript additions, but also frequently as stapled-on passages or instructive notes to the printer.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The galleys are presented in the order in which the archivist encountered them. None of the sets appears complete. Chapter numbers, titles, and bank and slide ranges (i.e., the numbering system used in production of the sheets) are listed to enable the researcher to locate desired sections of the book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed draft of LBJ Vol 1 and galley of Vol 1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed draft of PowerBroker, with edits. Galley of LBJ Vol 1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript draft (or drafts) of LBJ, Vol 1. Galleys of LBJ, Vol 1

did.unittitle: File cabinet 3.1 (1 of 2 boxes). LBJ. Label reads: Path to Power: LCRA; SC 1: Bios: Clark, Ed; Corcoran. (original drawer labels for FC 3 are in this box at front). (File cabinet 3 was the one that was jammed; Alan broke the lock and Bob scanned drawers. He decided to keep drawer 3, which had LBJ material he wanted.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 37 folders. Bulk of the files concern the LCRA (Lower Colorado River Authority), circa late 1930s-early 1940s. Rest relate to campaigns of 1938-44, though there may be connections. The content includes annotated photocopies of articles, correspondence, memos, etc. from the LBJ library and elsewhere, with Caro's typed notes and impressions from his reading of various sources. The only interviews I saw were a few handwritten notes in the last folder. A central focus here seems to be on A.J. Wirtz, who was Undersecy of the interior and later General Counsel for the LCRA. One document that might be particularly interesting is a 1975 memoir of the LCRA's history, from a Mary Rather who worked for Wirtz & LBJ (in LCRA Morrison folder). there is a small notebook in the box, but it seems mostly personal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 29 folders. Most relate to SCI (Senate Campaign I), 1941. Original campaign ephemera in the "Senate Campaign I" folder. Content same as above (photocopies, notes, typed summaries). Set of biographical folders on Edward A. Clark (Austin attorney & LBJ supporter), including a 1983 interview and write-up on Clark by Jordan Cowman. Set of biolgraphical files on Thomas Corcoran. Various folders are about Caro and the books: a folder "Vol. II, Ina's comments" have her perspective on sources; photocopies of articles about Caro (1980s); "Path: Reviews" includes book reviews for that and Power Broker'; and "Nice letters" includes some letters to Caro.There is one audiocassette tape; "March 23, 1983. Posh Oltorf, Continuation of George Brown interview"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 8 copies of Vol 1's "uncorrected proof."

did.unittitle: Box from back room: MSS outlines for LBJ Vol 1 (Leland Olds) and Desks of the Senate. Also: file folders for NYA and Sorensen OH were written on the box, but not noted in original manifest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Principal thing in this box are 7 folders with Ina's notes, photocopied documents, etc. on National Youth Administration (NYA), which seems to relate to African-American employment here. There is also a folder, notepads, and loose pages of Caro outlines and chapter sketches for LBJ volumes; largely disorganized but relates mostly to Leland Olds, building a relationship with Richard Russell as path to Presidency, and Senate history. Also in box:7 books (3 Texas almanacs, 1 on Allan Shivers, 3 on what appear to be topics of more personal interest (one has 2 snapshots including one of Caro, 1980s?). A bound copy of Theodore Sorenson oral history from JFK Library. And there are also various personal things floating around here: offer for a film of the Power Broker, speaking engagements, account statement(s), insurance offer, articles and references about Caro that he seemed to set aside for publicity use, etc.

did.unittitle: Series V. The Years of Lyndon Johnson [2]: Means of Ascent (published 1990)
File cabinet 3.2 (1 of 2 boxes). LBJ. Label reads: Means of Ascent: SC II. (original drawer label in box P39)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 48 folders. All on Senate Campaign II (SC II). Includes drafts, outlines, research notes, photocopies. Folder on Salas that includes Caro's notes/extracts from the manuscript (maanuscript is in box 101). The folder "SC II Summary" includes summaries/extracts from Caro's interviews, though I didn't see any full interview write-ups here.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 35 folders. Mostly or all continues with SC II. Folders on George Parr, Coke Stevenson (photograph, copy of oral history, etc) and material that relates to Caro's NYT article, with Ina's comments. Folders on Tom Clark. No interviews or original material jumps out. Mostly photocopies and typed notes.

did.unittitle: Loose Vol II LBJ MSS and 2 LBJ binders. From lower right shelf under binders from side room lower cabinet. This is material Bob identified on the spot for Larry to pull out and take.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript draft(s) of LBJ Vol 2, heavily edited/annotated. Two binders of photocopies of news clippings: 1949-53, 1954-57. the 2nd volume has what seems to be an index to the 2 binders.

did.unittitle: Home Sweet Home trunk 1 (1 of 3 boxes). Means of Ascent, etc

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Heavily edited and annotated drafts and outlines for LBJ, Vol 2 . In the middle of the box are many notepads and loose sheets that are difficult to pin down. Most seem to be related to LBJ Vol 2, but might also relate to Vol. 1. A few notes refer to Moses/Power Broker, but not substantial. A few of the sheets include lists of his target interviewees and a record of how many words a day he wrote during a particular period. There might be some interview notes in there. But generally no source documents here.

did.unittitle: Series VI. The Years of Lyndon Johnson [3]: Master of the Senate (published 2002)
File cabinet 4.1. (1 of 2 boxes). LBJ. Label reads: Vol. III Outlines, Senate: '49-'58, Senate Political Files (original file cabinet 4 drawer labels are in this box). (1 of 2)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 73 folders. The first many folders hold outlines for various parts of Vol 3 (Senate years). Also folders with Ina's comments on the volume, Andy Hughes's legal review, and the original letters from Senate Historian Ritchie with interesting comments on the volume. Many of these outlines seem to relate to the 1956 civil rights bill. The rest of the folders are subject-oriented with the usual mix of photocopies of news articles and documents from the LBJ library and elsewhere, Caro's typed summaries of his sources (no interviews jumped out), and outlines. Principal topics seem to be Senate history in general, LBJ's first year in Senate (1949), his 1955 heart attack, and much on the Senate and LBJ in 1956.

did.unittitle: File cabinet 4.1. (2 of 2 boxes) LBJ. Vol III.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 37 folders continues from above. Research files on Senate politics and biographies of select figures. Sources are mostly LBJ Library, but some significant material from Thomas Corcoran papers at Library of Congress and various oral histories from Southern senators (folder indicates summaries are from Ina). Photocopies (notably of George Reedy and and office memos, and some chapters of unpublished Corcoran MSS), Caro summaries of sources.

did.unittitle: File cabinet 4.2. (1 of 2 boxes) LBJ. Vol III. Label reads: Sen: '49 - Longoria, Olds; Eisenhower & Johnson; Senators' Bios; Oilmenl Library: review requests; Sen: CR-Bernstein; Master: Special Letters. (original drawer label in box P45)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 53 folders. First several folders relate to the Felix Longoria matter (1949), re discrimination against Mexican-American; some interview summaries here done by Ina. The rest of the folders (bulk of box) relate to Leland Olds matter (LBJ opposition to his FPC reappointment on behalf of oilmen). Photocopies from LBJ, FDR, & Truman libraries. Summary notes. A couple folders of Caro interviews on this subject/

did.unittitle: File cabinet 4.2. (2 of 2 boxes) LBJ Vol III.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 56 folders. First couple folders continue from above re: Leland Olds. Then a set of folders on the Eisenhower (DDE)/LBJ relationship, whichmaterial from the Ike Library and an extensive "memo" from Ina with source/research summaries. Many folders on various senators; the most substantive seems to be in the Paul Douglas folders. several folders on oilmen, including Clint Murchison, Sid Richardson, and Wesley West. Back of box has LBJ Library donor review letters approving or not access to material. Finally, several folders of "special letters" which seem to be praise from readers of Power Broker and LBJ, including a letter from jourmalist Tom Wicker.

did.unittitle: Trunk 5. LBJ. Mss of Master of the Senate. Some chapters, incl Senate History, The Last Caucus, Preparedness. Legal pads with handwritten drafts. Typescripts with pencil editing by me. Typed Mss that went to Knopf. (1 of 3 boxes) (Original label from trunk is in this box.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inbox with typescript draft of parts of LBJ Vol 3. Legal pads with outlines, also of Vol 3? A second inbox with typescript drafts of Vol 3.

A love letter card between the Caros.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Trunk 7. LBJ MSS (6 of 6 boxes) Floppy discs in here.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Heavily edited and Post-its of LBJ Vol 3 typescript drafts. About 26 3.5 inch floppy disks of chapters. One microcassette tape, not labeled, but appears to have been used.

did.unittitle: Trunk 8. LBJ in various in-boxes (1 of 2 boxes). (I kept the content of each in-box roughly segregated in the box, but not sure if each box really had a theme.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Content of 4 in-boxes re: LBJ, Vol 3. Legal pads of outlines, notes, early drafts; typescripts of draft chapters; photocopies of Congressional record, news articles and documents from LBJ and Eisenhower Libraries, probably among others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Content of 4 in-boxes re: LBJ, Vol 3. According to Caro's box notes, these are from his desk at 250 W. 57th at the end of the book. Includes outlines for "there was no law to help him" and "The rising tide." (A file on civil rights as related drafts in here). Also rough draft typescripts of Longoria. Wall outlines and early drafts on legal pads. All very messy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: LBJ, appears to be all Vol 3. Various drafts (typescripts, rough page proofs, revised proofs).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: LBJ, appears to be all Vol 3. Various drafts (rough page proofs, revised proofs).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Appears to have material related to the first 3 volumes of LBJ. Early typescript, heavily edited drafts and several legal pads of handwritten outlines/drafts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Portion of typescript drafts of LBJ Vol 1 and Vol 3. 2 unopened copies of audiobook of Vol 3. Badly stained typescript draft and outline of Caro's intended novel.

did.unittitle: Series VII. The Years of Lyndon Johnson [4]: The Passage of Power (published 2012)

File cabinet 5.1. LBJ Vol IV. Passage of Power: outlines, JFK, assassination legal pads/drafts, left on desk at end of Vol IV. (Original drawer label in box) (file cabinet 5 was one of two taken by N-YHS)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Research files for LBJ, Vol 4. Bulk of box has files on JFK assassination: photocopies of documents from LBJ Library, JFK Library, other sources, newspaper clippings (original and photocopies). Also has files of "outlines" of the subject matter with Caro's point and indicators of his sources for those points. Some files on JFK and footnotes. Several "legal pads left on desk at end of Vol IV." No original interview notes or original period documents stood out here.

did.unittitle: File cabinet 3.4 (1 of 2 boxes). LBJ. Label reads: Vol. IV; Running for the nomination; VP: Accepting it; Ken-Johnson Cmpn; Vice-Presidency (original drawer label in Box P39)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 80 folders. About LBJ running for 1960 Presidential nomination, accepting the VP position, and 1960 campaign. See folder "General" for Caro's notes to self on how to approach "running for nom" topic; "Newspapers" has Caro's notes with reference to Ina's notebooks with 1960 nclips (binders?); "Claudia's late find" with materials from an assistant researcher(?) (her name pops up here and there in Caro's notes/files). Photocopies of documents, annotated, with Caro's typewritten or handwritten outlines and source summaries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 51 folders related to LBJ's VP years, including civil rights, Cuban missile crisis, and other. Usual assortment of photocopies from LBJ and other libraries, etc (now some Internet/Google accessed stuff appears), outlines, note to self, summaries of sources.

did.unittitle: File cabinet 2.1. (1 of 2 boxes). LBJ. Label reads: IV. Passage of Power; Introduction: drafts; Vice Presidency; Taking Charge. (original drawer label from file cabinet 2 is in this box)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 35 folders. Most of the folders relate to LBJ as VP, with later folders on "taking over" or "taking command" after JFK death. Civil rights appear a lot (St Augustine folders), but not exclusively. Heavy photocopies of George Reedy documents and other material from LBJ Library. Also Caro's outlines and stiching together of quotations and points to be made from various sources. Often the notes give reminders and instructions to "you," presumably to himself. "VP: Senate" folder has letter to Caro from Don Oberdorfer pointing out some disagreement he has with Caro's points in re: LBJ/Mansfield/Bobby Baker.

did.unittitle: File cabinet 2.1 (2 of 2 boxes). Continues LBJ, Vol IV

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 51 folders. Continues from above with all folders on topic of "taking over" or "taking command." Folder with pad of notes taken as Caro listened to NBC News (JFK funeral). Folder: Diary Back-up includes Caro's notes to self about his notetaking. A folder of copies from the TIME files (maybe we have these now), or may TIME-related from other sources? Lots of photocopies from LBJ Library, including speeches of 1963-64. Civil rights a sub-theme here.

did.unittitle: Box from back room: labeled as "last from desktop at end of Vol IV." And also contents of 2 wooden in-boxes. Notes, folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box holds documents of working files from 3 Caro piles from his desktop and wooden in-boxes he used to keep more or less related things. (The in-boxes themselves did not fit in the record cartons so we did not pack them, but we used folders to identify the breaks in content of each box.) Overall these materials relate to LBJ Vol 4, especially it seems on "taking command" and the 1964 civil rights bill. They include outlines and prelim drafts (mostly of the Intro), notes to self (pep talks, reminders) and Ina, photocopies (especially on JFK assassination) from LBJ Library. There are also letters and emaiils from various people offering to meet to tell their own LBJ stories or conveying short anecdotes. Some folders hold requests for speaking engagements, book tour, and the like. A few folders relate to publication of Ina's Paris travel book. Book: Halberstam's Best & Brightest.

did.unittitle: Series IX. Working: Researching, Interviewing, Writing (published 2019)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thirty-one scrapbooks documenting Robert Caro's career, from his beginnings at the Horace Mann School, through his days as an investigative journalist for Newsday, and, ultimately, the publication of his seminal works on Robert Moses and Lyndon B. Johnson. While the earliest three volumes focus on his school and Newsday writings, the bulk of the scrapbooks—largely assembled by Ina Caro—hold a mix of materials charting the publication and reception of each of Caro's books to date. They include a broad mix of materials, from reviews and newspaper interviews, best seller lists, telegrams and letters (and in later years, emails), publicity tour schedules, photographs taken at signings and award ceremonies, invitations to dinners, and various pieces of ephemera, such as program brochures and place cards.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The scrapbooks are filed chronologically, although there is some overlap in coverage between volumes. The contents of each volume are given in notes in the container list. Numbers in [brackets] preceding each item represent the pages of the scrapbook; in cases where a page contained multiple items, these are listed separately and assigned a suffix: "a," "b," "c," etc. While the volumes labeled "Scrapbook [A]," "Scrapbook [B]", and "Scrapbook [C]", are listed here, they are more fully described in Series I and Series II.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Spine embossed "3." Mostly contains Power Broker reviews, publicity, awards, and letters.
[Numbers in brackets represent the pages of the scrapbook. Pages containing multiple items are marked "a," "b," etc.]
[01] "Caro and Mayhew Win Book Award," Washington Monthly, March 5, [1975].
[02] Letter, Mary Williams [Safio?], August 7, 1975.

[03] Letter, Joel S. Freeman, President, Library Associates of Brooklyn College, informing Caro he is the recipient of their annual Distinguished Service Award for 1975, November 7, 1974. With invitation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:

But he's also turning out a novel about journalism, focusing on an investigative reporter, for Knopf. Sort of a busman's holiday for Caro, who spent six years as an investigative reporter for Newsday.")

The Lyndon Johnson appearing in Caro's prose is not a fiction. There was such a man'."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Cover embossed "2019-Working." Contains mostly reviews and publicity of Working: Researching, Interviewing, Writing, and the acquisition of Caro's papers by the New-York Historical Society.
[Numbers in brackets represent the pages of the scrapbook. Pages containing multiple items are marked "a," "b," etc.]
